questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions  I am a rather elderly man. The nature of my avocations for the last thirty years has brought me into more than ordinary contact with what would seem an interesting and somewhat singular set of men, of whom as yet nothing that I know of has ever been written:—I mean the law-copyists or scriveners. I have known very many of them, professionally and privately, and if I pleased, could relate diverse histories, at which good-natured gentlemen might smile, and sentimental souls might weep. But I waive the biographies of all other scriveners for a few passages in the life of Bartleby, who was a scrivener of the strangest I ever saw or heard of. While of other law-copyists I might write the complete life, of Bartleby  nothing of that sort can be done. I believe that no materials exist for a full and satisfactory biography of this man. It is an irreparable loss to literature. Bartleby was one of those beings of whom nothing is ascertainable, except from the original sources, and in his case those are very small. What my own astonished eyes saw of Bartleby, that is all I know of him, except, indeed, one vague report which will appear in the sequel.  Ere introducing the scrivener, as he first appeared to me, it is fit I make some mention of myself, my employées, my business, my chambers, and general surroundings; because some such description is indispensable to an adequate understanding of the chief character about to be presented.  Imprimis: I am a man who, from his youth upwards, has been filled with a profound conviction that the easiest way of life is the best. Hence, though I belong to a profession proverbially energetic and nervous, even to turbulence, at times, yet nothing of that sort have I ever suffered to invade my peace. I am one of those unambitious lawyers who never addresses a jury, or in any way draws down public applause; but in the cool tranquility of a snug retreat, do a snug business among rich men’s bonds and mortgages and title-deeds. All who know me, consider me an eminently safe man. The late John Jacob Astor, a personage little given to poetic enthusiasm, had no hesitation in pronouncing my first grand point to be prudence; my next, method. I do not speak it in vanity, but simply record the fact, that I was not unemployed in my profession by the late John Jacob Astor; a name which, I admit, I love to repeat, for it hath a rounded and orbicular sound to it, and rings like unto bullion. I will freely add, that I was not insensible to the late John Jacob Astor’s good opinion.       Source: Bartleby, the Scrivener - Herman Melville

questions.question_text_1: Read the following exchange between a student and a professor and answer the given subquestions:    Abeer: Hi, Professor Sriram. My name is Abeer. Prof. Sriram: Hi, Abeer. How can I help you?  Abeer: I was told that you place students in internships for various university programs. Prof. Sriram: Yes.  Abeer: Well, I am interested in the internship at the university art museum… what responsibilities interns have, what qualifications they need to have... Prof. Sriram: Sorry, those positions are all filled for this year...  Abeer: Oh! But I just saw the announcement on the museum website this morning. Prof. Sriram: Unfortunately, the website is out of date.  Abeer: I want to do museum work after I graduate, and the job experience would look great on my résumé. Plus it's the only paid internship on campus. Prof. Sriram: I understand. However, there are some other ways to get some work experience, even if it's not exactly what you want. For instance, the library is looking for student volunteers.  Abeer: The library? But... Prof. Sriram: Well, they're planning an exhibition of photographs documenting the history of the university. And they're looking for student volunteers to help go through the archives and select images that'll show how the university's changed over the last hundred years.  Abeer: Hmm... Prof. Sriram: Now that's only a four-week project, I think. And, of course, it's unpaid.  Abeer: But it would be something to put on my résumé... Prof. Sriram: Exactly. Why don't you read the job description—it's posted on the library's website. If you're interested, let me know, and I'll put in a good word for you with Geeta Raj. She's the library's exhibitions director and will be interviewing applicants.  Abeer: OK, I'll do that right away.

questions.question_text_1: Fill in the blanks with correct expressions of numbers/values/quantity and answer the given subquestions.   Global economic activity is experiencing a broad-based and sharper-than-expected slowdown, with inflation (1) _____________________ than seen in several decades. The cost-of-living crisis, tightening financial conditions in most regions, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and the lingering COVID-19 pandemic all weigh heavily on the outlook. Global growth is forecast to slow from 6.0 percent in 2021 to 3.2 (2)______________________ in 2022 and 2.7 percent in 2023. This is the weakest growth profile since 2001 except for the global financial crisis and the (3) _______________________ phase of the COVID-19 pandemic. Global inflation is forecast to rise from 4.7 percent in 2021 to 8.8 percent in 2022 but to decline to (4) ______________________________ 6.5 percent in 2023 and to (5) ______________________ 4.1 percent by 2024. Monetary policy should stay the course to restore price stability, and fiscal policy should aim to alleviate the cost-of-living pressures while maintaining a sufficiently tight stance aligned with monetary policy.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"English 2" (Foundation Level, Semester 2)** exam, based on the provided question paper.
The exam focuses on **4 major areas**:
1. **Reading Comprehension** (Literary Passages)
2. **Grammar & Syntax** (Sentence Structure, Voice, Mood, Clauses, etc.)
3. **Vocabulary & Semantics** (Synonyms, Antonyms, Word Stress, Syllables)
4. **Pragmatics & Communication** (Dialogues, Politeness, Intonation, Discourse Markers)

---

---

### **1. Reading Comprehension (Literary Passage: *Bartleby, the Scrivener* by Herman Melville)**
#### **Key Themes & Concepts**
- **Narrator’s Perspective**: First-person narration by an elderly lawyer describing his profession and employees (scriveners).
- **Character Analysis**:
  - **Bartleby**: A mysterious, enigmatic scrivener with no known background ("nothing is ascertainable").
  - **Narrator**: Unambitious, prudent, methodical lawyer who avoids conflict ("easiest way of life is the best").
- **Literary Devices**:
  - **Irony**: The narrator’s admiration for "prudence" contrasts with Bartleby’s passive resistance.
  - **Symbolism**: Bartleby represents alienation; the narrator’s office symbolizes bureaucracy.
- **Vocabulary in Context**:
  - **Avocation** (hobby/pursuit) vs. **vocation** (profession).
  - **Asccertainable** (determinable/verifiable) vs. **uncertain**.
  - **Tranquility** (calmness) ↔ **chaotic** (antonym).
  - **Snug** (comfortable/cozy).

#### **Critical Questions to Address**
- Why is Bartleby’s lack of biography an "irreparable loss to literature"?
  *(Answer: His uniqueness and mystery make him a compelling but undocumented figure.)*
- How does the narrator’s personality contrast with Bartleby’s?
  *(Answer: Narrator = pragmatic, social; Bartleby = passive, isolated.)*

---

### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
#### **A. Sentence Structure & Clauses**
| **Concept**               | **Definition**                                                                 | **Example**                                                                 |
|---------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Adjunct**               | Optional adverbial phrase modifying the sentence.                             | *"After she has had her dinner"* in *"Anuradha is leaving after she has had her dinner."* |
| **Adjectival Clause**     | Dependent clause modifying a noun.                                           | *"who developed the algorithm"* in *"Reena, who developed the algorithm, was honored."* |
| **Complement Clause**     | Clause acting as the subject/object complement.                              | *"that Hari will walk in"* in *"He is sure that Hari will walk in."*        |
| **Relative Clause**       | Introduced by relative pronouns (*who, which, that*).                         | *"which was postponed earlier"* in *"The competition, which was postponed, was held."* |
| **Simple/Compound/Complex Sentences** | Classification by clause structure.                                   | *"Rohan resigned and joined a new company."* (Compound)                     |

#### **B. Voice & Mood**
| **Concept**       | **Active → Passive Conversion**                              | **Example**                                                                 |
|-------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Active Voice**  | Subject performs the action.                                 | *"The banker counted the money."*                                           |
| **Passive Voice** | Object becomes the subject.                                 | *"The money was counted by the banker."*                                    |
| **Indicative Mood** | States facts.                                               | *"Ajay won the championship."*                                              |
| **Subjunctive Mood** | Hypothetical/uncertain actions.                            | *"If I were you, I would apologize."* (Not tested here but relevant.)      |

#### **C. Tenses & Verb Forms**
| **Tense**                 | **Structure**                     | **Example**                                                                 |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Past Progressive**      | *was/were + V-ing*                | *"Bilal was visiting Lucknow."*                                            |
| **Present Perfect**       | *has/have + V3*                   | *"There has been an increase in enrollment."* (Present Perfect Continuous) |
| **Future Perfect**        | *will have + V3*                  | Not directly tested, but contrast with other tenses.                       |

#### **D. Question Forms & Tag Questions**
- **Interrogative Conversion**:
  - *"You closed the door yesterday."* → *"Did you close the door yesterday?"*
- **Tag Questions**:
  - *"She destroyed the whole system, didn’t she?"*

---

### **3. Vocabulary & Semantics**
#### **A. Synonyms/Antonyms**
| **Word**         | **Synonym**       | **Antonym**       |
|------------------|-------------------|-------------------|
| **Avocation**    | Hobby             | Vocation          |
| **Asccertainable** | Determinable     | Uncertain         |
| **Tranquility**  | Calmness          | Chaos             |
| **Snug**         | Comfortable       | Uncomfortable     |

#### **B. Word Stress & Syllables**
| **Word**          | **Stressed Syllable** | **Syllable Count** |
|-------------------|-----------------------|--------------------|
| **Destiny**       | 1st (*DES-ti-ny*)     | 3                  |
| **Midnight**      | 1st (*MID-night*)     | 2                  |
| **Suppressed**    | 2nd (*su-PRESSED*)    | 2                  |
| **Substantially** | 2nd (*sub-STAN-tial*) | 4                  |
| **Utterance**     | 1st (*UT-ter-ance*)   | 3                  |
| **Dedication**    | 2nd (*de-di-CA-tion*) | 4                  |

#### **C. Idioms & Phrases**
| **Phrase**          | **Meaning**                          |
|---------------------|--------------------------------------|
| **Faux pas**        | Social blunder/inappropriate behavior |
| **Modus operandi**  | Method of action (e.g., criminals)  |
| **Lifted the spirits** | Cheered up/made happy             |

---

### **4. Pragmatics & Communication**
#### **A. Dialogue Analysis (Abeer & Professor Sriram)**
- **Key Themes**:
  - **Politeness Strategies**: *"Could you please give me those reports?"* (vs. *"Give me those reports"*).
  - **Disappointment & Alternatives**: Abeer’s reaction to the unavailability of the museum internship.
  - **Compromise**: Professor suggests an unpaid library project as an alternative.
- **Critical Questions**:
  - Why does Abeer want the museum internship? *(Career goals: "I want to do museum work after I graduate.")*
  - What is the library exhibition about? *(Photographs documenting the university’s history.)*

#### **B. Intonation & Pauses (Audio-Based Questions)**
- **Stress Patterns**: Identify stressed syllables (e.g., *DES-ti-ny*).
- **Sentence Pauses**: Use `//` for major pauses, `/` for minor pauses in speeches (e.g., Nehru’s *"Tryst with Destiny"*).
  - Example:
    > *"Long years ago/ we made a tryst/ with destiny// and now/ the time comes/ when we shall redeem our pledge..."*

#### **C. Polite Requests & Suggestions**
| **Situation**               | **Polite Form**                          | **Impolite Form**               |
|-----------------------------|------------------------------------------|----------------------------------|
| Asking for reports          | *"Could you please give me those reports?"* | *"Give me those reports."*       |
| Making a suggestion        | *"Shall we make a move?"*                | *"Let’s move."* (less polite)   |

---

### **5. Miscellaneous Concepts**
#### **A. Bound Roots & Morphemes**
- **Bound Roots**: Morphemes that cannot stand alone (e.g., *-tain* in *retain*, *-ceive* in *receive*).
  - *"They received money to retain the player."* → **2 bound roots** (*re-**ceive**, **re-**tain*).

#### **B. Metaphors & Literal Meaning**
- **Metaphor**: A word/phrase with non-literal meaning (e.g., *"time is a thief"*).
  - Statement: *"Metaphors are words or phrases that do not have literal or direct meaning."* → **True**.

#### **C. Negative Forms**
- *"He liked her very much."* → *"He **did not** like her very much."*

#### **D. Conjunctions & Connectors**
- **Whether vs. If**:
  - *"I was consulting with him **whether** to consider their proposal."* (Not *"if"* for formal choices.)
- **Cause-Effect Connectors**:
  - *"The team members were tested positive. **As a result**, the match was called off."*

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Reading Comprehension (*Bartleby, the Scrivener*)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Bartleby the Scrivener] --> B[Narrator: Elderly Lawyer]
    A --> C[Bartleby: Mysterious Scrivener]
    B --> D[Traits: Prudent, Methodical]
    B --> E[Philosophy: 'Easiest way of life is best']
    C --> F[Traits: Passive, Enigmatic]
    C --> G[Significance: 'Irreparable loss to literature']
    A --> H[Themes]
    H --> I[Alienation]
    H --> J[Bureaucracy]
    H --> K[Irony]
```

#### **Graph 2: Grammar & Syntax**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Sentence Structure]
    B --> C[Simple/Compound/Complex]
    B --> D[Clauses]
    D --> E[Adjunct]
    D --> F[Adjectival]
    D --> G[Complement]
    D --> H[Relative]
    A --> I[Voice]
    I --> J[Active]
    I --> K[Passive]
    A --> L[Tenses]
    L --> M[Past Progressive]
    L --> N[Present Perfect]
```

#### **Graph 3: Vocabulary & Semantics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Vocabulary] --> B[Synonyms/Antonyms]
    B --> C[Avocation ↔ Hobby]
    B --> D[Tranquility ↔ Chaos]
    A --> E[Word Stress]
    E --> F[Destiny: 1st Syllable]
    E --> G[Midnight: 1st Syllable]
    A --> H[Idioms]
    H --> I[Faux Pas]
    H --> J[Modus Operandi]
```

#### **Graph 4: Pragmatics & Communication**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Pragmatics] --> B[Dialogues]
    B --> C[Politeness: 'Could you...?']
    B --> D[Disappointment: Abeer's Reaction]
    A --> E[Intonation]
    E --> F[Stress Patterns]
    E --> G[Sentence Pauses: '//' and '/']
    A --> H[Requests]
    H --> I[Polite: 'Shall we...?']
    H --> J[Impolite: 'Give me...']
```

---
### **Key Equations/Rules (For Grammar)**
1. **Active → Passive Voice**:
   - **Formula**: *Object + [be] + V3 + by + Subject*
     - Example: *"The banker counted the money."* → *"The money **was counted** by the banker."*
2. **Tag Questions**:
   - **Formula**: *Auxiliary + not + Subject?* (for positive statements)
     - Example: *"She destroyed the system, **didn’t she**?"*
3. **Past Progressive Tense**:
   - **Formula**: *Subject + was/were + V-ing*
     - Example: *"Bilal **was visiting** Lucknow."*

---
### **Exam Tips**
1. **Reading Comprehension**:
   - Focus on **character traits**, **themes**, and **vocabulary in context**.
   - Practice **summarizing** passages in 2-3 sentences.
2. **Grammar**:
   - Master **clause identification** (adjectival, adverbial, complement).
   - Practice **active-passive conversions** and **tense recognition**.
3. **Vocabulary**:
   - Memorize **synonyms/antonyms** and **stress patterns** for audio-based questions.
4. **Pragmatics**:
   - Pay attention to **politeness levels** in dialogues.
   - For **intonation questions**, listen for pauses (`//`, `/`) in speeches.
